Award.AwardTitle: Crystal Size Effects on the Lattice Parameter of Nano-scaled Oxides
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Prof. Siu-Wai Chan is examining how nanosized crystals expand or contract at the atomic level, and how they are affected by crystal size, temperature, pressure, and the presence of structural irregularities. The intellectual value of her research lies in understanding how small structural changes make profound changes in material behavior. This enhanced understanding will help in the development of new materials with improved properties. A better understanding of bonding should contribute to the development of nanoparticle synthesis methods with greater control over critical properties. Insight into the structure and defects in metal oxide nanoparticles may provide a knowledge base for the rational design of more efficient and less costly catalysts for cleaner air and sustainable energy. Undergraduate, master's, and doctoral students are being trained in conducting research, and new demonstration units (that incorporate the results of this study) are being developed for a New York City high school visitation program.

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Prof. Siu-Wai Chan is examining changes in the lattice parameter of metal oxides with crystallite-size, defect formation, temperature, and pressure. She employs both traditional and synchrotron-based, time-resolved X-ray diffraction. The coefficient of thermal expansion is calculated through measurements of the lattice in response to temperature variations. Similarly, measuring how the lattice responds to pressure allows for a calculation of the bulk modulus. She is interested in determining if these quantities are dependent on particle size in the nanoscale regime. The intellectual value of her research lies in the fact that small structural changes often generate profound changes in properties. Therefore, this project will provide a window to view the nature of bonding in nanoparticles and will enable a better understanding of surface stress and surface energy to be gained. It will also help to determine if the macroscopic based theory of surface stress, which has successfully predicted the lattice contraction in noble metal crystallites, can be used for ionic solids. The opportunity to tackle these issues is timely because mono-dispersed nanoparticles are now widely available.

Intellectual Merit:

Oxides are important materials for the advancement of emerging technologies. Size-control of nano-oxides provides a new knob to control their properties and to realize new, innovative devices. This will only be possible if we know how their properties change with size.

In the 1980’s, the electronic and optical properties of semiconductor crystallites were shown to be meticulously controlled by the physical size of the nano-crystals. These properties have led to successful integration of these colorful nano-particles (known as quantum dots) into display devices. In comparison, the possible crystal-size dependence of important fundamental physical properties such as bond-length, thermal expansion, and compressibility or bulk modulus of nano-crystals has received little attention. The key outcome of this project is to fill this niche of missing information. The question is this: does size matter for these physical and mechanical properties for nano-oxides? And how?

Prof. Siu-Wai Chan and students examine changes in the lattice parameter of metal oxides with crystallite-size, temperature, and pressure. They employs both traditional and synchrotron-based, time-resolved X-ray diffraction.  The coefficient of thermal expansion is calculated through measurements of the lattice in response to temperature variations. Similarly, measuring how the lattice responds to pressure allows for a calculation of the bulk modulus.  These quantities are found to depend on particle size.  The intellectual value of the research lies in the fact that small size changes often generate significant changes in properties as we have observed in their size-dependent thermal and elastic properties. Therefore, this project has provided a window to view the nature of bonding in nanoparticles and has enabled a better understanding of surface stress and surface energy.  The macroscopic theory of surface stress, which has successfully predicted the lattice contraction in noble metal crystallites, can be used for nano ionic solids with the additional lattice expansion provided by surface-adsorbed layers on the nano-oxides.  We have the opportunity to tackle these issues today because mono-dispersed nanoparticles are now widely available. 

 

Broader of impact

 

Prof. Siu-Wai Chan and students have discovered that nanosized crystals expand at the atomic level with decreasing crystal size in five oxides. Further, the temperature and pressure responses of these nano-oxides were founded to depend on crystal-size.  The broader impact of the results lies in its challenge to the traditional understanding of thermal and elastic behavior of material.  Clearly thermal and elastic properties of nano-oxides are size-dependent different from those of the corresponding bulk oxides. This finding will ask if the text-book equation involving these quantities needs to be modified to include size-dependence. The reasons of the size-dependent thermal and elastic properties will help in the development of new materials with novel properties.  A better understanding of thermal and elastic behavior should contribute to the design and application of nano-oxides in innovative sensors and devices with greater control over critical properties.  Insight into the structure and bonding in metal oxide nanoparticles may provide a knowledge base for the rational design of more efficient and less costly catalysts for cleaner air and sustainable energy.  More than 10+ students from high school, colleges, master, and doctoral programs were trained in conducting research. Furthermore, a New York City high school was visited 3 times by PI and students.
